A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.

A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A group is defined as a monoid with additional properties. Therefore, the concept of a monoid must be defined to understand what a group is.

A subring is defined as a subset of a ring that is a subgroup with respect to addition and a submonoid with respect to multiplication. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a subring is.
A principal ideal domain is defined as a ring with specific properties. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a principal ideal domain is.
The greatest common divisor is defined in terms of divisibility within a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a greatest common divisor is.
The canonical homomorphism is defined as a ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a canonical homomorphism is.
A torsion element is defined in the context of an A-module. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined to understand what a torsion element is.
The Frobenius homomorphism is defined as a homomorphism of fields. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a Frobenius homomorphism is.

An algebraic closure of a finite field is defined as a field containing a finite field and all its algebraic extensions. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what an algebraic closure of a finite field is.

A splitting field of a polynomial is defined as a field extension where the polynomial splits into linear factors. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a splitting field is.
Disjoint cycles are defined in terms of sets. Therefore, the concept of a set must be defined to understand what disjoint cycles are.
